Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 11:06AM amanda1116 wrote: There is a risk inherent to MRI contrast dye to people with kidney disease but it is evidently low enough so that MRI with contrast continues to be used diagnostically and very safely. There is also a risk that anyone, anytime  and anywhere can be allergic to anything from contrast dye to a food, a nut product, any medication.  I a college friend whom, during college, had some not very major kidney issues and had an MRI with contrast and was allergic to the dye and died within minutes of injection.  That said I have had many routine breast MRIs and so have many people I know and not one of us has had any reaction to the dye.  I will say if you do it, drink a lot of water afterwards to flush your body of the contrast but it's no big deal.  Even for me, the ultimate neurotic patient.  I seriously had a colonscopy for the first time two days after Michael Jackson died and the ten minute soy based anesthesia they use for colonoscopy is the same drug he was given IV (and that killed him).  I was so freaked out that I refused any and all anesthesia.  Let me guarantee that the colonoscopy was horrible beyond words and all because I though I was going to instantly turn into Michael Jackson if I had the short acting anesthesia that he was addicted to.  That was the last time I will ever be that dumb.  Breast MRI is not perfect: it is too sensitive and not specific enough: BUT IT SAVES LIVES, and the contrast dye is an integral part of that.  Just my two cents
Posts.Title: Risks of MRI Scaredandworried Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: May 26, 2012 01:22PM amanda1116 wrote: May I tell you that my radiologist, one of the top in the country, says exactly the same thing as your sister when I carry on about having a yearly MRI.   I say noooo  I don't want to to this (I have had four resulting in 3 biopsies, all B9 but completely emotionally draining)  She said, and I quote: "You have a 15 year old daughter so suck it up and deal, Amanda"  And she is right.
Posts.Title: Radiologist and Surgeon Disagree LisaDVM Shayne

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 03:42AM - edited Aug 26, 2011 03:44AM by amanda1116 The myth that core needle or any other sort of biopsy "spread" cancer is just that: a myth. There is no true other way of diagnosing either benign or malignant disease other than pathology and pathology always requires biopsy.  That applies to virtually ANYTHING, not just breast cancer. The myth of spreading disease as a result of surgery or biopsy is a very old one and does not originate with breast cancer, it originated with neurosurgery in the 1940s and 50s.  There was an old saying that "you're never the same when the air hits your brain" They meant brain tumor resection which, at that time, was in its infancy (read John Gunther's DEATH BE NOT PROUD if you don't believe me). Patients were "never the same" back then because neurosurgery was so primative (in some cases still is). So don't worry about that as a reason for any sort of spreading disease -- at all!!!
Posts.Title: Preparing for biopsy Lavender250 Gottobme

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2011 11:45AM amanda1116 wrote: I'd defintely request Klonopin if I were you: it works very well in stress reduction in a high stress situaton and is pretty short acting. Be careful of some of the anti anxiety meds: Ativan is like the wonder drug but it is so addictive it's not funny and Valium can be so weird for some not all people. I took it only once right before I had all four wisdom teeth out.  First I kept seeing the dancing hippos from the Walt Disney movie FANTASIA and then I must have been looking very weirdly at the periodontist before he started and he said, laughing "Wow, Amanda, do you even know who I am?"  I said sure I do, you're Jim Cramer from "Mad Money" on CNBC -- do you still love Apple stock?  He was like "Um no that's not right."  I said "Okay -- are you Uncle Dave?" Uh, nope.   It was a real scene evidently.  He asked me to never ever ever take Valium again and would not let me leave after the teeth were out until I promised five times. Believe me I haven't.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 05:48AM amanda1116 wrote: You certainly can call in medical review at your ins company. Despite your age this sounds like a classic "mistake" made by someone sitting behind a desk somewhere.  I would remind them a) of your family history and b) that MULTIPLE papilloma, which entirely benign, carries with it a greater risk of later issues than SOLITARY intraductal papilloma (which carries none in and of itself).  I am sure that the person or people sitting at a desk do not know the difference between the two .  Arm yourself with info: there are many good sites which discuss both benign conditions but they are different.  Just my $0.02

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:59AM amanda1116 wrote: We are all drowning in our own fears at one time or another.  If it is not about breast cancer, it is about something else.  I mean that seriously. At other times, often miraculously, we are not. Your description of symptoms sound eerily familiar.  When I was 26 I had a fibro in one breast that was (or felt) enormous.  I had an open surgical biopsy to remove a small part of it for examination by the patholgists. The surgeon did not take more at that time because he did not want to leave me with an irregular looking breast.  I kept saying but what if it's cancer (my mother died of bc when I was a teenager) and he kept saying then we'll talk: right now this is what we are doing.  It was completely B9.  The huge fibro dissolved on its own over the next few years (it's barely there) but I remember being in a state of shock 1) because I was having breast surgery and was 30 years younger than my mom and 2) because I had NO IDEA really of what was going on.  I didn't even really understand a thing about the architectiure of the breast and this was stuff that happened to other people: at 26 I looked 15 and probably acted 13 about medical issues: either freaking or just like they didn't exist.  Hang in there, get it taken care of and I pray for your best results ever.  Sorry this isn't deeper or more meaningful but I think I know what you must be feeling and most of it is confusion that will be resolved Amanda

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2012 08:19PM amanda1116 wrote: Your concerns are absolutely valid and so are anyone's regarding a personal or health issue.  No one, and I repeat NO ONE, least of all a medical professional would term you a hypochondriac.  At least not publicly and never until they have ruled out your concerned. That kind of stuff is way more than politically correct right now: it is about a doctor's not winding up in a legal situation. So get it checked out and never feel anything but relief that your instincts told you to.  If it's "all in your head" hey -- all power to you.  That would be the best outcome ever!

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 06:28AM amanda1116 wrote: I know this is hard to do right now (I know from personal experience) but try to bear in mind that 80% of all breast lumps found on exam or diagnostic test are completely B9.  We are inundated with breast cancer news, and the scariest (I find) is the 1 in 7 thing (as in women who will get breast cancer).  However, that is over a lifetime and it means that 6 out of 7 will not be diagnosed with breast cancer.  The odds are very much in your favor.  I know this probably doesn't make you feel all that much better right now: this is only a website full of virtual strangers and even those we are close to sometimes can't really change or improve our fears or feeings.  But I bet diagnostic mammography and/or sonogram or MRI or whatever (if anything) is further recommended will improve them and soon!!!!  Good luck with this and most important: thank you for serving our country. Amanda

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 03:20AM amanda1116 wrote: I beg you not to wait.  Bear in mind your "keeping an eye on it" is really not an issue unless you yourself are a breast surgeon.  And even if you are those guys depend very heavily if not entirely  on radiologists and pathologists.  Please try to get qualified medical assistance.  This may be nothing serious at all (and probably is since the odds are in your favor) but you need to know.  All states have free mammography and even sonography programs, and as someone said above the law on pre-existing conditions and health care has changed in many states.  Good luck!!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: Update: waiting to see a dr waybacktexas kikiwiki

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 03:25AM amanda1116 wrote: Hi -- I had a wire guided solitary intraductal papilloma excision a week ago. It was found, very tiny, on a yearly MRI in June and biopsied. The entire papilloma was taken out at the time of biopsy but the standard here (in NYC) is to excise the duct and examine the tissue surrounding it for cancer, atypical cells etc.  I'm thankful beyond world to say that the the papilloma and all of the tissue around it was completely benign as the radiologist(s) and BS thought it would be.  Amen to that. The "worst" part of it was the wire location at my radiologist's on the morning of the surgery. And it was truly not even that bad.  The area was in a difficult location to get to very near the nipple and wire location is done via mammogram.  They had to do it three times to locate it perfectly, which they did.  The needle and wire are tiny and really do not hurt at all.  My poor radiologist had to sit on the floor under the mammo machine to get it right.  They work with my BS all the time (same hospital NYU Medical Center) and he is very exacting and very demanding.  I get the feeling one centimeter off and this guy flips out.  He is actually a very nice and hilariously funny guy (a funny breast surgeon, just what we all need -- but we do) except he is serious as they come in the o.r.  One tip they will tell you at the wire location: DO NOT LOOK DOWN while they are doing it.  That is not so you won't flip out: that is because if you do, your breast will move in the mammo machine. The surgery for me was honestly not a big deal.  I had it under a local and it took all of 20 minutes.  I didn't even have or want sedation.  I was a wreck from the time I had the MRI to through the biopsy and before the surgery but when it came time to have it, I basically just wanted it over and done. I've known my surgeon for 20 years (since I had a fibro in my early twenties which he biopsied -- it was very large and they only took a slice to look at -- completely benign) and he was kind enough to throw his weight around over at pathology and get the report and slides within 24 hours after the surgery so I could be done with all of this. Other than the stress factor, there is no horrible part to any of this.  It is multi step to err on side of caution, but single papilloma is pretty simple. be aware though that the tiny incision around the nipple can ooze fluid for up to two weeks while it heals. This is often because of where it is located and the fact that the weight of the breast is behind it (and I am only a B cup).  Wear a bra as much as you can after the surgery. even sleep in one for a few days to reduce pressure on the area that was operated on.  They will tell you that.   I actually found that the only tricky part of it is taking a week of precautionary antibiotics afterwards.  I am allergic to pennicillin and I had to take Clindamycin. That is one big gun antibiotic.  I had luckily taken it a year ago when I had my first and much more awful than this root canal to get rid of the infection (which is actually very dangerous) before the root canal.  I had never even heard of Clindamycin before and looked it up (of course) online since I am the world's biggest cyberchondriac and what I read about potential side effects shocked me  out of my head.  I didn't get any of them so when I had to take it again this past week, I was fine with it. Do though take the antibiotics even if you are very antt-antibiotics (like me). Good luck with this: I hope it is really easy for you!  I know that due your other medical issues, you will need a different standard of care than I had but I am praying that the results are exactly the same: B9 as they are almost always with papilloma!
Posts.Title: Having wire guided excisional Gottobme VSM

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 12:02PM amanda1116 wrote: The "fuzzy picture" may not be medically serious at all but be aware (really DO be aware) that MRI is an incredible tool but I don't want it to scare you.  There is a high rate of false positives (benign conditions that are NOT CANCER) that are always biopsied and very often removed after the biopsy. That's just the way it goes: humans are not as advanced as this particular technology yet. It is very sensitive and not very specific (unlike mammo and sono which are specific and not all that sensitive.  That said, it can find problems at their eariest and most curable and treatable stages.  Have you asked why MRI -- are you high risk?   I have had 3 MRIs (I am high-ish risk) and 3 biopsies and all were benign.  My radiologist told me that 85% of MRI findings are indeed benign.  Good luck with this and try to stay calm and believe me I know how hard that is -- very.   The MRI itself is not a huge deal at all.  It's a bit loud (they give you earplugs or music) but it's not painful (ie mammo) at all.  No squeezing.  Results are usually read very quickly.  Try to make sure you go to a DEDICATED MRI site.  That means if you need an MRI guided biopsy it can be done there.  I hope all turns out really really perfectly for you!!!  Ask me anything about breast MRI.  Due to my own insistence I know it all.  Amanda
Posts.Title: MRI this week positive12 SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 09:13AM amanda1116 wrote: The soy connection is a questionable one.  First of all soy protein and soy products are in so many things and the reason is very, very few people are allergic to soy (unlike milk for example). I will say that the connection between high consumption of red meat and alcohol and breats and other cancers may be many times greater than soy or soy products.  I don't any red meat or alcohol and never have (not for social or spiritual reasons, but simply because I hate the taste of both and always did. Even as a child, I would feel ill at the sight of red meat) That said, I eat fish I am pretty sure that some of what they insist is wild isn't and has more dangerous stuff it than any soy ever could.  I eat soy products in real moderation because of the breast cancer connection, but having spent years around Asian culture and visiting Asia (my daughter is adopted from China), Chinese and Japanese women eat soy sometimes at every meal and have the lowest rates of breast cancer in the developed world.  Only parts of Africa are lower.  What does this imply? I can't say but it is notable.
Posts.Title: Is soy ok to eat with a high risk of getting breast cancer? elizwal Blessings2011

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 02:38PM - edited Jan 30, 2013 02:39PM by amanda1116 I don't know if panic attacks can actually be avoided.  Meds will help but only with the symptoms and until the underlying cause is resolved or addressed. That's the key issue evidently and certainly easier said than done.   I've only had one genuine panic attack (I panic like everyone else, but an attack is different) and that was when I was a sophomore in college.  It seemed to have arisen out of nowhere: I woke up one morning in my dorm terrified with all of the symptoms of a panic attack.  I believe I must have had a nightmare and while I didn't remember the dream, I assume it was very frightening. The attack subsided after a few minutes in it's own but that was so long ago and I still remember how horrible it was.   So I feel for you and anyone who has them: it's as though for the person having an attack time has stopped and there is no way out while it is happening.  The good news is that the do subside and with meds may even be avoided! I will tell you one thing that worked for my daughter and perhaps it will help you (maybe not).  My daughter is the least panic-y person I have ever met (she is in 11th grade) but she is also one of the top womens saber fencers in the country.  At big competitions, she would win bouts all the way to the last few at the top and start to panic.  She's win, but anxiety, anxiety and this is in no way an anxious kid or athlete.  At least until she reachd the upper echelons of American fencing she wasn't.  A friend of hers, who is an Olympic saber fencer suggested that she see a sports psychologist he had worked with and she did. The sports psychologist was totally nice, very professional and incredible well credentialed. Most of what he discussed with my daughter both she and I found a bit simplistic.  Nothing that she could not have learned on the internet without paying a small fortune.   The one thing he did for her that really did work, however, was something I personally found so outdated and during it's time in the 1970s and 80s trendy and meaningless: biofeedback.  But perhaps I was judgmental and wrong because that now outdated remedy worked for my daughter for whatever reason.  After X number of sessions, she was never anxious at a fencing competition again.  Maybe she would have gotten over it on her own, but this speed it up.  I'm certainly not here to recommend it to others suffering anxiety, but it did work for her -- and I was shocked that it did since everything else the sports psychologist suggested basically made her laugh more than fixed the problem.  It really did work.
Posts.Title: I think I had my first panic attack...:/ Yell1724 Raineyb

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 10:14PM amanda1116 wrote: I'm so sorry you are going through this.  Truth is there is not a single person on this or any website that can diagnose you with "something" or "nothing" so you may believe you have "all the classic symptoms" but....of what?  Breast disease may be symptomatic or asymptomatic, whether benign or malignant.  If you were smart enough to come here to learn that everyone is basically telling you to have your symptoms assessed by a medical professional and you do so, you are not stupid at all, you are smart and you should LOVE not hate yourself for doing so.   Good luck as you move forward toward a resolve and congratulations on your new life. Remember, as a mom, if one of your kids came to you with unusual symptoms you would run not walk to their pediatrician with them.  Do the same for you!  Best.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 09:23PM - edited Nov 17, 2011 09:28PM by amanda1116 Hi, sharkbait My story is quite like yours in so many ways.  I too have mammo and MRI alternating every six months.  In fact I just had a mammo today (it was all clear).  The fear and anxiety are horrible surrounding the screenings.  I am more terrified of mammo than MRI for some reason and in two years the MRI picked up three things: two tiny fibros and a tinier papilloma.  That mean three biopsies and an open surgery, all B9. The mammo by the way has never seen a single abnormality (knock wood) and I have been having them since the age of 26 (20 years) I hate all of it and was and am a basket case for weeks before each mammo or MRI.  I seriously once was so thrilled that my mammo was A-OK that I pranced out of my doctor's office through what I thought was an open door which was a thick glass closed door, crashed into it head first, and got a concussion.   That is how out of it I am before during and after mammo (or MRI) day, week and month.  Scary That said we are so lucky to have technology like digital mammography and MRI.  Quite simply, they save lives.  Maybe yours or mine oneday.  If you can afford it and can bear the stress, I say go for it.  I am seriously the most freaked out breast care patient I have ever me and even I just grit my teeth and go through this crap.  My radiologist (who is wonderful) told me I have young daughter, if I am not doing this for me, do it for her and just suck it up.  Never a truer word was spoken.  By the way, you posted this yesterday, November 16th, which is my daughter's birthday :) :)
Posts.Title: Six Months Rotation... sharkbait DocBabs

Posts.Content: amanda1116 wrote: SO many of you write that you found a doctor/specialist/surgeon uncaring and clinically cold.  Warmth and people skills are not something they teach in medical school and yes they should (actually some are starting to) but forget that: you are more than a patient, you are client the second money (whether yours or an insurance company's) changes hands and the client is always right.  Demand the right to being treated civilly and with compassion at a stressful time from EVERYONE you meet in the medical profession who has something to do with your case.  I am sure it is what you would offer them if the tables were turned (I sure would).  These are the "Amanda Rules" (I'm Amanda) and since the day I decided to enforce them when I was 20 years old, not a single medical professional has not treated me with the same respect I show them!  Works in life, too actually but is essential in a stressful situation involving potential breast disease!!  Just my two cents to those of you who have been treated poorly by ANYONE you have had to work with in the very large world of breast health and disease, diagnosis and treatment and cure.   Best to all,  Amanda Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Medical professional cold and uncaring? Follow my rules amanda1116 amanda1116

It is very hard for ANYONE to remember that, but it's true.  A good radiologist or BS or anyone else you see IS naturally concerned about everything and anything and this is a very good thing for patients, all patients. Good luck and my wishes are with you!!
Posts.Title: the biopsies are done... vanlex amanda1116

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 04:32PM amanda1116 wrote: Hi Melissa Being called back for more pictures in and of itself doesn't really mean anything.  I mean sure it does, but is not indicative that anything is of of concern at all necessarily. Many radiologists ask for additional films when films are not clear or areas of the breast within that film are not as defined as they would like.  Tissue can overlap other tissue obscuring the film. It's happened to me many many times (I go to a radiology practice and the MD is right there looking at the digital pix a second later).  Once I could have sworn my breast wasn't compressed tightly enough in the machine and sure enough it wasn't: redo.  Once they took six pictures of one breast and I freaked out of course.  My radiologist came in afterwards and said no no you're fine: the picture just wasn't clear enough until the tech "spread" your breast in the machine.  Hope this is of some help!
Posts.Title: UhOh !!! Melissa_P amanda1116

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 10:21PM amanda1116 wrote: Waiting for results is so awful.  Like beyond words.  I think for women it is as stressful as waterboarding and much more stressful than actually getting results.  I agree that telling you it may be malignant and leaving it at that is terrible.  That is also not appropriate at all: a pathologist needs to do his or her job before any other medical professional makes such pronoucements.    I sometimes get the feeling radiologists in general don't really know what to say or how to say it or to whom.  They are in a medical subspecialty where they tend not to know their patients all that well as people and therefore do not really know how to approach each individual patient or what he or she needs to hear and to process and how -- so sometimes they are blunt and dismissive, sometimes so kind you'd think this was preschool as in so super nice nice nice it;s kinda creepy -- and everything and anything in between.   Arm yourself with questions and bring either someone with you to take notes or remember or a tape recorder.  That Klonopin anti anxiety stuff works great too. You not only feel calmer and more in control but you can think straight and not be off in the ozone.  I myself loved Ativan the entire two times I took what was probably 0000000.5 mg (very little) til I found out how addictive it is (Klonopin is not addictive)  Good luck all good hopes and wishes for you

Posts.Title: What is that? ANewSong SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 08:00AM amanda1116 wrote: SASSYLADY I am not sure whether everyone goes to see a surgeon or not but it's a wise idea.  Radiologists are there to diagnose via technology and biopsy (well a pathologist diagnoses the biopsy of course)  But remember even if a biopsy is b9 it is a biopsy: it is not a guarantee that whatever is biopsied has been fully removed. There are many completely b9 conditions that should be removed completely so they do not recur and patients do not find themselves having more biopsies for same issue later.  The only person who can do this is a breast surgeon, so don't let his or her job title freak you out at all even after a b9 biosy.  Not all b9 conditions become a surgical recommendation, but many -- maybe most I can't say -- do.  And there are few radiologists who will not refer to a breast surgeon for most issues: it's their jobs on the line if they don't.  That is their responsibility and I think we have to respect that.  That is the drawback to medicine today and it's a legal issue.  I hope all goes really for you and that you remember that most breast masses and nodules are benign: about 80% on mammo and ultra and as many as 90% on MRI (which will pick of everything and cannot really differentiate as to what is what as all enhances with contrast thus the false positive rate is very high: remember though that false positive is false positive for breast cancer, not for benign conditions)   Hope this helps. Amanda
Posts.Title: Waiting For Biopsy Results :-( Rockym Sereena

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2011 09:59PM amanda1116 wrote: I am so sorry you had such a negative experience!!  If you feel that the standard of care you received was in fact substandard, I would suggest that you'd be doing yourself and other patients a huge favor by putting your grievances in writing and addressing it to whomever is the head physician of the practice (whether your own doc or another). I would use the word "aggrieved" -- doctors and almost anyone else knows that when you use this it is often a precursor to legal action. If you do not receive an adequate response in writing or by phone, feel free call either your local AMA division or the local radiology board and forward your letter.  You should DEFINITELY seek a second opinion if you feel the first opinion was superficial or may have overlooked any aspect of your initial complaint. Reading of uncaring medical professionals just horrifies me.  Any subspecialty of medicine is meant to be more than a job, it's meant to be a vocation.  Bad doctors are not only the ones who make horrible mistakes, they are those that do not care. Hippocrates said it best: "first do no harm" Harm in this case is a patient who feels their needs were not met!  Good luck and good thoughts to you

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 02:04PM amanda1116 wrote: I have a 15 year old daughter too so I hear you.  I also MRI. biopsy and surgery for a benign intraductal papilloma during the past month.  Try to step outside of your fears (which are completelty normal) long enough to get all of your questions answered by your medical team.  Write them down if you have to and either bring someone with you when you speak or tape record the session whether in person or by phone. You will find that quite helpful to listen to or discuss later. Levels, by the way, of what? Don't forget that 80% of breast nodules and masses are B9 and that even if you have a problem, you are empowering yourself and giving yourself the best odds by dealing with it early. This is hard to do -- the going through all this stuff -- but you and everyone else on these boards are doing it.  There are millions of women who are not, unfortunately. So bravo to you! These forums are very good: informationally and in terms of support.
Posts.Title: Very Scared sweetnkind amanda1116

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 02:05AM - edited Nov 19, 2012 02:06AM by amanda1116 Carly I have a daughter two years older than you are so I am going to tell you what I would tell any of her friends.  If you really don't feel comfortable talking to your mom or other family members, I assume from your age you are in either 8th or 9th grade.  Please go talk to the school nurse if you have one.  In addition to better hands on medical advice than you will get from a website where no one really knows what your symptom or symptoms actually mean with no diagnosis, I am sure she will direct you to more expert medical advice.  This certainly does not sound like like something "serious" mostly because of your age, but who am I to say that -- a stranger on a website, that's all.  Think back as to whether you bumped or injured yourself at any time recently is a good first step to look into as well. Even a soccer ball or gym class can indeed cause an injury!  Seriously, if you don't feel you want to discuss this with your mother or others in the family right now, do see your school nurse.  Perhaps she can help you to address this with either your mom or your pediatrician.   Good luck.  You're a smart, brave girl to visit this site with your questions and lots of girls your age wouldn't even think to do so so I hope you are proud of yourself. And Carly don't keep Googling your symptoms without some real medical advice.  Anyone here will tell you that is a very bad mistake...

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 07:14AM amanda1116 wrote: Absolutely get a second opinion.  Solitary papoillomas and clusters or groups of papillomas are quite different.  And with the history you write about, it's just my opinion but I would push for an MRI as well.  Papillomas are not always visible on either mammo or sono.  Also you need a surgeon whom you can relate to and understand well.
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon and so Confused-Please Help Nurseash85 Blessings2011

Posts.Content: amanda1116 wrote: Hey guys  Had both MRI guided biopsies on Wed. and yesterday.  First one, left, was a kinda big deal in that it was MRI guided and deep in breast. Did it, and surprisingly, so little pain or discomfort afterwards.  Biopsy results: another very tiny fibroad, no problem,case closed.  My breast isn't even bruised Right side yesterday: nodule much tinier near nipple.  Biopsy easy but OMG what huge bruising and it hurts a lot.  Biopsy just back:  tiny papilloma.  Not cancer but it must be taken out by my breast surgeon.  Small problem: radiologist feels she may have removed the whole thing (it was that small) when she did the biopsy.  Meeting with breast surgeon on Tuesday morning.  Oddly I have known him and his family for 26 years ever since at like 20 I had and had removed, a fibroadenoma.  Actually more like a biopsy: it was huge and he didn't want to take the whole thing for fear of making me completely lopsided.  It turned out both medically and aesthetically fine. Been seeing him regularly ever since. I hear papilloma and of course went nuts but the trusty radiologists + internet have quickly assuaged my fears. This too shall be resolved (very soon if I know my breast surgeon) -- the medical part.  But I need help, no joke.  All of what drives me is related to my mother's death from breast cancer AND the fact that if I see one more pink display in the media I will flip out.  I am DELIGHTED that women and medicine have made such progress with breast cancer -- 1000000000%  What I am not delighted about is how damaging the chatter has really been to someone like me.  It has taken me all these years and this board really to understand that I have post traumatic stress and it's not going away until I choose to do something about it and I'm on it now.  I will not spend another ten days like the last ten days, it is so damaging to every aspect of my existence.  I am yes also seriously going to be thinking about prophy bi lat mastectomy and immediate recon and discussing that with breast surgeon (and plastic surgeon who he works with who is fabulous and one of the biggest jerks I have ever met: one of those Dr. Park Avenue Board Certified guys that I know too well: I used to own a huge medical pr firm and half the clients were clones of this dud. Ah yes, get the guy on Good Morning America to discuss his famous short scar facelife and he's God.  Yuck.  If I go this route I suppose I have to grit teeth and bear it.  This guy really likes me for some reason.  I think it is my bone structure I dodged the bullet in bc three times in two years and you know what: I may have done enough bullet dodging to last lifetime on this subject.  Now I have to recover from all of this and do some work on my head. The most amazing thing about my recent journey was something my best friend from high school said to me.  Her best friend from college had breast cancer at 43 and honestly believes it was stress induced and that stress will always contribute to any disease.  Perhaps she is correct, I cannot say.  What I can say is that my belief is that the stress I feel from the entire subject of breast cancer is going to make me sick.  A kind of weird concept: stress causes illness and so does the stress of fear of illness.   Anyhoo, thank you all for being there for me and not saying "You'll be fine" like the other 200 people I know and am related to did.  I will be fine but only when I commit to getting rid of this wolf constantly beating down my door!! Amanda  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Follow up on Amanda amanda1116 amanda1116

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 06:16PM amanda1116 wrote: This could be so many things including allergic reaction to almost anything, or viral (I had West Nile with many of the same symptoms believe it or not), even sinus or inner ear infection or even vertigo or a virus that mimics it or, really and I am not just saying this, stress with a capital S.  In the absence of your oncologist on vacation, have you seen your internist or family physician? WIshing you only the best re results Amanda
Posts.Title: symptoms of brain mets? sandiedbella sandiedbella

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 08:40PM amanda1116 wrote: Bring a tape recorder.  You may not remember the details of what you discuss and there may be terms you do not understand and may wish to look up later.  Also if you listen to the tape you may find you have more questions to ask post-consult.
Posts.Title: Seeing breast surgeon on Tuesday velvetelvis chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 09:31PM amanda1116 wrote: I would say almost everyone here at any risk at all is tired of all this testing.  My own radiologist told me to suck it up (those words and she's terrific and I adore her).  We all do this breast stuff and no one wants to but we have to: it is our responsibility to ourselves or so popular theory says.  Yeah, right, I say: that makes perfect sense until you are in the middle of a mammo, sono or MRI You certainly can have a radiologist read all of this right away, depending on where you live and basically in some cases whether you are cool with shelling out the $$$ upfront if your insurance tells you you can't go there. I live in New York and go to a practice that is FANTASTIC except they take NO INSURANCE at all.  They read everything right away with you there except the MRI which takes an hour or so and they call you so fast. You need to find a practice like that if the wait time makes you crazy (it would make me insane, I am not joking) And you have to be okay with paying for it and then submitting.  You will probably not get back your entire fees because as we all know in healthcare destroyed America "customary and reasonable" for an insurer seems to have little bearing on what is charged.  I actually believe it or not went two (TWO -- miracle of miracles) without getting called back.  That was after yearly MRIs that always requires (B9 thank goodness) biopsies and an open surgery for a papilloma that wasn't there because it was taken out completely along with the surrounding tissue at the biopsy the week before...it's never ending.  Thing is you're here and it sounds like you are doing well and that is what is important. Amanda
Posts.Title: Would like for just 1 time to not have to get called back clevelandgirl99 Infobabe
